Description: A type of dizziness caused by changes in head position, often resulting from the inner ear's otolith organs being disturbed.
Cause: Dislodged otoconia in the inner ear.
Management: Canalith repositioning maneuvers (e.g., Epley), vestibular exercises.

Description: An intestinal illness caused by the parasite Entamoeba histolytica, leading to symptoms like diarrhea, stomach pain, and cramping.
Cause: Protozoan infection (Entamoeba histolytica) via contaminated food/water.
Management: Metronidazole followed by a luminal agent; rehydration and supportive care.

Description: A condition where the body lacks sufficient healthy red blood cells, leading to symptoms like fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath.
Cause: Nutritional deficiencies, blood loss, chronic disease, or genetic disorders.
Management: Nutritional supplements (iron, B12, folate), dietary changes, or transfusions if severe.

Description: An inflammation of the joints, causing pain, swelling, and stiffness. It can affect people of all ages and is common in older adults.
Cause: Joint inflammation from autoimmune processes (rheumatoid) or wear-and-tear (osteoarthritis).
Management: NSAIDs, DMARDs, physical therapy, lifestyle modifications, and sometimes surgery.

Description: A parasitic infection caused by roundworms, often resulting in abdominal pain, nausea, and malnutrition.
Cause: Ingestion of Ascaris lumbricoides eggs from contaminated soil/food.
Management: Anthelmintic drugs (e.g., albendazole) and improved sanitation/hygiene.

Description: A chronic condition that causes difficulty breathing due to inflammation and narrowing of the airways in the lungs.
Cause: Airway inflammation triggered by allergens, infections, or irritants.
Management: Inhaled bronchodilators, corticosteroids, trigger avoidance, and an asthma action plan.

Description: A fungal infection caused by an overgrowth of Candida, which can affect various parts of the body, including the mouth, skin, and genitals.
Cause: Overgrowth of Candida (often due to antibiotics, diabetes, or immunosuppression).
Management: Topical or systemic antifungals and addressing underlying risk factors.

Description: A degenerative condition affecting the bones and discs of the neck, often leading to pain, stiffness, and sometimes numbness in the arms.
Cause: Age-related degenerative changes in the cervical spine.
Management: Physical therapy, pain relievers, proper posture, and ergonomic adjustments.

Description: No detailed description available.
Cause: Varicella-zoster virus infection.
Management: Supportive care (antipyretics, antihistamines), antivirals for high-risk cases, and vaccination for prevention.

Description: A viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes, causing fever, joint pain, and rash, similar to dengue but with distinctive symptoms.
Cause: Viral infection transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes.
Management: Supportive care (rest, hydration, NSAIDs for pain) and mosquito control measures.

Description: A condition where bile flow from the liver is impaired, leading to symptoms like jaundice, itching, and fatigue.
Cause: Impaired bile flow due to intrahepatic/extrahepatic causes.
Management: Ursodeoxycholic acid, treatment of the underlying cause, and sometimes surgical intervention.

Description: A viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes, characterized by high fever, severe headache, rash, and joint pain.
Cause: Viral infection transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes.
Management: Supportive care (hydration, fever management) and close monitoring for complications.

Description: A chronic condition where the body cannot properly process glucose, leading to high blood sugar levels. It can be managed through lifestyle changes and medication.
Cause: Insulin deficiency/resistance (Type 1 and Type 2) with genetic and lifestyle influences.
Management: Lifestyle modifications, blood sugar monitoring, oral hypoglycemics, or insulin therapy.

Description: Swollen blood vessels in the rectal area that cause pain, bleeding, and itching, often due to straining or prolonged sitting.
Cause: Swollen veins due to straining, constipation, or increased venous pressure.
Management: High-fiber diet, sitz baths, topical treatments, and in severe cases, surgical procedures.

Description: An adverse reaction to a medication that can result in a range of symptoms, from mild rashes to life-threatening conditions like anaphylaxis.
Cause: Adverse or hypersensitivity reaction to medications.
Management: Discontinuation of the offending drug, supportive care, antihistamines, or corticosteroids.

Description: A parasitic disease caused by filarial worms, leading to lymphatic system damage and symptoms like swelling, fever, and pain.
Cause: Parasitic infection by filarial worms transmitted by mosquitoes.
Management: Antiparasitic medications (diethylcarbamazine) and vector control measures.

Description: An infection of the stomach and intestines, often caused by viruses or bacteria, leading to diarrhea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
Cause: Inflammation of the GI tract from viral, bacterial, or parasitic infections.
Management: Rehydration, electrolyte replacement, dietary modifications, and antibiotics when indicated.

Description: No detailed description available.
Cause: Acid reflux due to a weakened lower esophageal sphincter.
Management: Lifestyle modifications, antacids, H2 blockers, and proton pump inhibitors.

Description: A sexually transmitted bacterial infection that can cause symptoms like painful urination, discharge, and pelvic pain.
Cause: Bacterial infection (Neisseria gonorrhoeae) transmitted via sexual contact.
Management: Dual antibiotic therapy (e.g., ceftriaxone and azithromycin) and partner treatment.

Description: A viral liver infection often transmitted through contaminated food or water, leading to symptoms like jaundice, fatigue, and abdominal pain.
Cause: Viral infection transmitted through contaminated food/water.
Management: Supportive care (hydration, rest) and vaccination for prevention.

Description: A viral infection affecting the liver, typically transmitted through contaminated water. It causes jaundice and can be severe in pregnant women.
Cause: Viral infection spread via the fecal-oral route (contaminated water).
Management: Supportive care (hydration, rest) and preventive measures in endemic areas.

Description: A parasitic infection where hookworms enter the body through the skin, leading to symptoms like abdominal pain, diarrhea, and anemia.
Cause: Parasitic infection through skin contact with contaminated soil.
Management: Anthelmintics (albendazole or mebendazole) and iron supplementation if needed.

Description: A condition characterized by high blood pressure, which can lead to serious complications like heart disease and stroke if left untreated.
Cause: Multifactorial (genetics, high salt intake, obesity, stress).
Management: Lifestyle changes, antihypertensive medications, and regular monitoring.

Description: A condition where the thyroid gland produces too much thyroid hormone, leading to symptoms like weight loss, rapid heartbeat, and nervousness.
Cause: Overactive thyroid due to Graves’ disease, nodules, or thyroiditis.
Management: Antithyroid drugs, radioactive iodine therapy, or surgery as indicated.

Description: A condition where blood sugar levels drop too low, causing symptoms like shakiness, dizziness, and confusion.
Cause: Low blood sugar from insulin overdose, fasting, or excessive exercise.
Management: Fast-acting carbohydrates and adjustment of diabetic medications.

Description: A condition where the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormone, leading to symptoms like fatigue, weight gain, and depression.
Cause: Underactive thyroid (commonly Hashimoto’s thyroiditis or iodine deficiency).
Management: Thyroid hormone replacement (levothyroxine) and regular monitoring.

Description: A viral respiratory infection that causes fever, cough, sore throat, and muscle aches. It is highly contagious and spreads easily.
Cause: Viral infection by influenza viruses.
Management: Supportive care, antivirals (if early in illness), rest, and annual vaccination.

Description: No detailed description available.
Cause: Elevated bilirubin due to liver disease, bile duct obstruction, or hemolysis.
Management: Treat underlying cause, supportive care, and monitoring of liver function.

Description: A chronic infectious disease caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium leprae, affecting the skin, nerves, and mucous membranes.
Cause: Chronic infection with Mycobacterium leprae.
Management: Multi-drug therapy (dapsone, rifampicin, clofazimine) and early diagnosis.

Description: A mosquito-borne infectious disease caused by parasites, leading to symptoms like fever, chills, and fatigue.
Cause: Parasitic infection by Plasmodium species via Anopheles mosquito bites.
Management: Antimalarial drugs (e.g., chloroquine, artemisinin derivatives) and prophylactic measures.

Description: A highly contagious viral infection causing symptoms like a rash, fever, and cough. It is preventable through vaccination.
Cause: Viral infection spread by respiratory droplets.
Management: Supportive care, vitamin A supplementation, and MMR vaccination for prevention.

Description: A severe headache often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. Migraines can last for hours to days.
Cause: Neurological disorder with multifactorial triggers (hormones, stress, foods).
Management: Pain relievers, triptans, preventive medications, and lifestyle modifications.

Description: A viral infection causing swelling of the salivary glands, often accompanied by fever, headache, and muscle aches.
Cause: Viral infection transmitted by respiratory droplets.
Management: Supportive care, isolation, and MMR vaccination to prevent infection.

Description: A degenerative joint disease that causes the cartilage in joints to wear down, leading to pain, stiffness, and decreased mobility.
Cause: Degenerative joint disease from cartilage wear and tear.
Management: Pain management, physical therapy, weight management, and sometimes joint injections/surgery.

Description: A condition where sores develop in the lining of the stomach or the first part of the small intestine, often caused by infection or excessive use of NSAIDs.
Cause: Ulceration from H. pylori infection or prolonged NSAID use.
Management: Eradication of H. pylori (if present), acid suppression (PPIs/H2 blockers), and dietary modifications.

Description: An infection that inflames the air sacs in the lungs, causing symptoms like fever, cough, difficulty breathing, and chest pain.
Cause: Lung infection from bacteria, viruses, or fungi.
Management: Appropriate antibiotics (if bacterial), supportive care (oxygen, fluids), and sometimes antivirals/antifungals.

Description: A chronic autoimmune skin condition that causes the rapid growth of skin cells, leading to scaly, red patches, often on the elbows, knees, and scalp.
Cause: Chronic autoimmune skin disorder with genetic and environmental factors.
Management: Topical therapies, phototherapy, and systemic treatments (e.g., methotrexate, biologics).

Description: A contagious viral infection characterized by a rash, fever, and swollen lymph nodes, often affecting young children.
Cause: Viral infection spread via respiratory droplets.
Management: Supportive care, isolation, and MMR vaccination to prevent transmission.

Description: A skin infestation caused by mites that leads to intense itching and a rash, typically transmitted through close personal contact.
Cause: Infestation by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei.
Management: Topical scabicides (e.g., permethrin) and treating close contacts.

Description: An inflammation or infection of the sinuses, often causing symptoms like nasal congestion, headache, facial pain, and a runny nose.
Cause: Inflammation/infection of the sinuses (viral, bacterial, or allergic).
Management: Decongestants, nasal saline irrigation, and antibiotics if bacterial infection is confirmed.

Description: A sexually transmitted bacterial infection with distinct stages: primary (ulcers), secondary (rash), latent, and tertiary (organ damage).
Cause: Bacterial infection by Treponema pallidum via sexual contact.
Management: Penicillin therapy (or alternatives for allergies) and partner treatment.

Description: A parasitic infection caused by tapeworms, leading to symptoms like abdominal discomfort, nausea, and weight loss.
Cause: Parasitic infection from ingestion of tapeworm eggs/larvae (often from undercooked meat).
Management: Anthelmintics (praziquantel or albendazole) and improved food hygiene.

Description: A bacterial infection causing muscle stiffness and spasms, often triggered by a deep wound or puncture. It can be life-threatening without treatment.
Cause: Clostridium tetani infection from contaminated wounds.
Management: Tetanus immunoglobulin, antibiotics, wound care, and vaccination boosters.

Description: A genetic blood disorder that causes the body to produce an abnormal form of hemoglobin, leading to anemia, fatigue, and other complications.
Cause: Inherited blood disorder affecting hemoglobin production.
Management: Regular blood transfusions, iron chelation, and possible bone marrow transplant.

Description: A parasitic infection caused by Toxoplasma gondii, often transmitted through contaminated food or contact with cat feces, affecting the brain and eyes.
Cause: Parasitic infection by Toxoplasma gondii via contaminated food or cat feces.
Management: Combination therapy (pyrimethamine, sulfadiazine, folinic acid) for severe cases; supportive care.

Description: A sexually transmitted parasitic infection caused by Trichomonas vaginalis, leading to symptoms like itching, discharge, and discomfort.
Cause: Sexually transmitted protozoan infection (Trichomonas vaginalis).
Management: Single-dose metronidazole or tinidazole for patient and partners.

Description: A bacterial infection primarily affecting the lungs but can affect other parts of the body, causing symptoms like cough, chest pain, and weight loss.
Cause: Bacterial infection by Mycobacterium tuberculosis via airborne droplets.
Management: Long-term multi-drug therapy (e.g., isoniazid, rifampicin, ethambutol, pyrazinamide) with DOTS.

Description: A bacterial infection caused by Salmonella Typhi, leading to fever, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. It is spread through contaminated food or water.
Cause: Infection by Salmonella typhi via contaminated food/water.
Management: Antibiotic therapy (ciprofloxacin, azithromycin) and supportive care.

Description: An infection in any part of the urinary system, often causing symptoms like painful urination, frequent urination, and pelvic pain.
Cause: Bacterial infection (commonly E. coli) ascending from the urethra.
Management: Antibiotics, increased fluid intake, and pain relievers.

Description: A viral disease transmitted by mosquitoes, causing fever, chills, and jaundice. It is preventable through vaccination.
Cause: Viral infection transmitted by Aedes or Haemagogus mosquitoes.
Management: Supportive care, vaccination for prevention, and mosquito control measures.

Description: A viral infection spread by mosquitoes, often causing mild fever, rash, and joint pain. It can be harmful during pregnancy.
Cause: Viral infection transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes or sexual contact.
Management: Supportive care (hydration, rest), and prevention via mosquito control and safe sex practices.

Description: Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome caused by the HIV virus, leading to a weakened immune system, making the body more susceptible to infections.
Cause: HIV infection transmitted via blood, sexual contact, or perinatal exposure.
Management: Antiretroviral therapy (ART) and management of opportunistic infections.

Description: Liver inflammation caused by excessive alcohol consumption, leading to symptoms like jaundice, abdominal pain, and nausea.
Cause: Liver inflammation from chronic excessive alcohol consumption.
Management: Complete abstinence from alcohol, nutritional support, and corticosteroids in severe cases.

Description: A bacterial infection caused by Bacillus anthracis, often affecting the skin, lungs, or digestive system, and can be fatal if untreated.
Cause: Bacterial infection by Bacillus anthracis from exposure to infected animals/spores.
Management: Prompt antibiotic therapy (ciprofloxacin, doxycycline) and supportive care.

Description: A rare condition where the bone marrow fails to produce enough blood cells, leading to fatigue, infections, and uncontrolled bleeding.
Cause: Bone marrow failure due to autoimmune, toxins, drugs, or viral infections.
Management: Immunosuppressive therapy, blood transfusions, and bone marrow transplant if indicated.

Description: A rare but serious fungal infection affecting immunocompromised individuals, often leading to severe tissue damage.
Cause: Fungal infection by Mucorales fungi, often in immunocompromised patients.
Management: Aggressive antifungal therapy (amphotericin B) and surgical debridement.

Description: A type of cancer that originates in the bladder lining, causing symptoms like blood in urine, frequent urination, and pain during urination.
Cause: Often linked to smoking, chemical exposures, or chronic irritation.
Management: Surgical resection, chemotherapy, radiation, or intravesical therapy.

Description: Cancer that begins in the bones, often causing pain, swelling, and fractures.
Cause: Primary (e.g., osteosarcoma) or metastatic lesions in bone.
Management: Surgery, chemotherapy, and/or radiation therapy.

Description: A common form of cancer that originates in the breast tissue, causing lumps, changes in breast shape, and skin dimpling.
Cause: Multifactorial with genetic (BRCA), hormonal, and environmental factors.
Management: Surgery, chemotherapy, radiation, hormone, and targeted therapies.

Description: Cancer of the cervix, often caused by persistent infection with certain types of human papillomavirus (HPV), leading to abnormal cell growth.
Cause: Persistent infection with high-risk HPV strains.
Management: Surgical interventions, radiation, chemotherapy; prevention via HPV vaccination.

Description: A bacterial sexually transmitted infection that can cause symptoms like painful urination, discharge, and pelvic pain.
Cause: Bacterial infection by Chlamydia trachomatis via sexual contact.
Management: Antibiotics (azithromycin or doxycycline) and partner treatment.

Description: No detailed description available.
Cause: Viral infection by SARS-CoV-2 transmitted via respiratory droplets.
Management: Supportive care, antivirals (remdesivir), corticosteroids, oxygen therapy, and vaccination.

Description: A parasitic infection caused by larvae of the tapeworm Taenia solium, which can affect muscles, eyes, and the brain.
Cause: Parasitic infection by Taenia solium larval cysts from contaminated food/water.
Management: Antiparasitic agents (albendazole or praziquantel) often with corticosteroids; sometimes surgery.

Description: A bacterial infection that causes a thick coating in the throat, leading to breathing difficulties, fever, and weakness.
Cause: Bacterial infection caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae transmitted via respiratory droplets.
Management: Administration of diphtheria antitoxin, antibiotics (penicillin or erythromycin), and vaccination for prevention.

Description: A viral hemorrhagic fever caused by the Ebola virus, leading to severe bleeding, organ failure, and high mortality rates.
Cause: Viral hemorrhagic fever transmitted through contact with infected bodily fluids.
Management: Supportive care (fluids, oxygen), experimental antivirals/monoclonal antibodies, strict isolation and infection control measures.

Description: Cancer that develops in the esophagus, often leading to difficulty swallowing, weight loss, and chest pain.
Cause: Risk factors include chronic GERD, smoking, alcohol, and dietary influences; can be squamous cell carcinoma or adenocarcinoma.
Management: Treatment may include surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or a combination depending on stage.

Description: A genetic disorder that can cause red blood cell breakdown in response to certain triggers, leading to hemolytic anemia.
Cause: Inherited enzymatic defect leading to reduced protection against oxidative stress.
Management: Avoidance of known triggers (certain drugs, fava beans), supportive care during hemolytic episodes, blood transfusions if necessary.

Description: A condition that occurs when blood flow to a part of the heart muscle is blocked, leading to chest pain, shortness of breath, and other symptoms.
Cause: Coronary artery blockage (atherosclerotic plaque rupture leading to thrombosis).
Management: Emergency reperfusion therapy (thrombolytics or PCI), antiplatelet agents, beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors, and lifestyle modifications.

Description: A genetic disorder that affects blood clotting, leading to excessive bleeding and difficulty stopping bleeding after injury.
Cause: Inherited deficiency of clotting factors (commonly factor VIII or IX).
Management: Replacement therapy with the deficient clotting factor, prophylactic infusions, and supportive measures to manage bleeding.

Description: A viral liver infection that can lead to chronic liver disease and cirrhosis, spread through contact with infected bodily fluids.
Cause: Viral infection transmitted via blood or bodily fluids.
Management: Antiviral medications (e.g., tenofovir, entecavir), monitoring liver function, and vaccination for prevention.

Description: A viral infection of the liver that can lead to chronic liver disease and liver cirrhosis, often spread through blood-to-blood contact.
Cause: Viral infection primarily transmitted via blood exposure.
Management: Direct-acting antiviral regimens that can cure most cases, with monitoring for liver complications.

Description: A viral infection that occurs only in those already infected with Hepatitis B, leading to more severe liver disease.
Cause: Occurs only in those already infected with hepatitis B; caused by the hepatitis D virus.
Management: Limited treatment options (pegylated interferon in some cases); prevention via hepatitis B vaccination is key.

Description: A type of lymphoma, a cancer of the lymphatic system, causing symptoms like swollen lymph nodes, fever, and weight loss.
Cause: Malignancy of lymphatic tissue characterized by Reed-Sternberg cells; exact cause unclear but may involve viral and genetic factors.
Management: Chemotherapy and radiation therapy are the main treatments; in advanced cases, stem cell transplantation may be considered.

Description: Cancer that starts in the kidneys, often causing symptoms like blood in urine, pain in the side, and unexplained weight loss.
Cause: Often renal cell carcinoma; risk factors include smoking, obesity, and hypertension.
Management: Surgical resection (partial or radical nephrectomy), targeted therapies, immunotherapy, and/or radiation therapy depending on stage.

Description: A cancer of the blood cells that affects bone marrow and blood, leading to symptoms like fatigue, frequent infections, and easy bruising.
Cause: Malignancy of blood-forming tissues; can be acute or chronic, lymphocytic or myeloid.
Management: Chemotherapy, targeted therapies, radiation, and possibly hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

Description: Cancer that begins in the liver, often causing symptoms like abdominal pain, jaundice, and weight loss.
Cause: Associated with chronic hepatitis (B or C), cirrhosis, and aflatoxin exposure.
Management: Treatment options include surgical resection, liver transplantation, ablation therapies, and chemotherapy/targeted therapy.

Description: A type of cancer that originates in the lungs, leading to symptoms like coughing, chest pain, and difficulty breathing.
Cause: Most commonly caused by cigarette smoking; also linked to environmental exposures and genetic factors.
Management: Options include surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and targeted/immunotherapies based on cancer type and stage.

Description: A cancer of the lymphatic system that causes swollen lymph nodes, fever, night sweats, and weight loss.
Cause: A group of blood cancers affecting the lymphatic system; causes include genetic and environmental factors.
Management: Treatment typically involves chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and immunotherapy; treatment is tailored to the subtype.

Description: A cancer of the lymphatic system that includes various types of lymphoma other than Hodgkin's lymphoma, often presenting with swollen lymph nodes and unexplained weight loss.
Cause: Diverse group of lymphatic malignancies not characterized by Reed-Sternberg cells.
Management: Management includes chemotherapy, immunotherapy, and sometimes radiation therapy, depending on the specific subtype and stage.

Description: Cancer that begins in the pancreas, leading to symptoms like abdominal pain, weight loss, and jaundice.
Cause: Associated with risk factors such as smoking, chronic pancreatitis, diabetes, and genetic predisposition.
Management: Often treated with surgery (e.g., Whipple procedure), chemotherapy, and radiation; early detection is challenging.

Description: Loss of muscle function due to bleeding in the brain, often resulting from trauma or a stroke.
Cause: Bleeding in the brain (intracerebral hemorrhage) due to hypertension, aneurysm rupture, or trauma causing nerve damage.
Management: Emergency stabilization, surgical intervention if needed, and comprehensive rehabilitation therapies.

Description: A bacterial infection caused by Yersinia pestis, often spread by fleas, leading to symptoms like fever, swollen lymph nodes, and septicemia.
Cause: Bacterial infection caused by Yersinia pestis transmitted by flea bites from infected rodents.
Management: Prompt antibiotic treatment (streptomycin, doxycycline) and supportive care; public health measures are critical during outbreaks.

Description: A viral infection that can cause paralysis, often affecting children and leading to permanent disability.
Cause: Viral infection transmitted via the fecal-oral route, historically causing paralysis.
Management: No cure; supportive care, physical therapy, and prevention via vaccination (OPV/IPV).

Description: Cancer of the prostate, leading to symptoms like difficulty urinating, blood in the urine, and pain in the pelvis.
Cause: Risk increases with age and genetics; hormonal factors also play a role.
Management: Options include active surveillance, surgical removal, radiation therapy, hormone therapy, and chemotherapy based on stage.

Description: A viral infection that affects the nervous system, often transmitted through animal bites, leading to confusion, aggression, and hydrophobia.
Cause: Viral infection transmitted via the bite or scratch of an infected animal.
Management: Post-exposure prophylaxis (wound cleaning, rabies immunoglobulin, and vaccination) is critical; once symptomatic, it is nearly always fatal.

Description: A genetic disorder that causes red blood cells to become abnormally shaped, leading to pain, anemia, and potential organ damage.
Cause: Genetic mutation leading to abnormal hemoglobin that causes red blood cells to sickle.
Management: Pain management, hydroxyurea, blood transfusions, and supportive care; bone marrow transplant may be considered in select cases.

Description: Cancer that forms in the skin cells, often appearing as growths or lesions. Types include melanoma, basal cell carcinoma, and squamous cell carcinoma.
Cause: Primarily due to UV radiation exposure and genetic predisposition; includes melanoma, basal cell, and squamous cell carcinomas.
Management: Treatments range from surgical excision to topical therapies, cryotherapy, radiation, and systemic therapies for advanced cases.

Description: Cancer of the stomach, leading to symptoms like abdominal pain, bloating, and loss of appetite.
Cause: Associated with chronic H. pylori infection, high-salt diets, smoking, and genetic factors.
Management: Managed with surgical resection, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy, often in combination.

Description: A condition where there is a low platelet count, leading to symptoms like easy bruising, excessive bleeding, and petechiae.
Cause: Low platelet count due to various causes including autoimmune disorders, medications, or bone marrow problems.
Management: Treat the underlying cause, corticosteroids, platelet transfusions, and supportive care as needed.

Description: A parasitic infection caused by Schistosoma worms, leading to symptoms like blood in the urine, abdominal pain, and urinary frequency.
Cause: Parasitic infection by Schistosoma haematobium from contact with contaminated freshwater.
Management: Treatment with praziquantel and improvements in sanitation and water quality to prevent reinfection.

Description: A skin condition characterized by pimples, blackheads, and cysts, often occurring in adolescence but can affect people of all ages.
Cause: Inflammatory condition due to clogged hair follicles, bacteria, and hormonal influences.
Management: Topical retinoids, antibiotics, benzoyl peroxide, and in severe cases, oral medications (antibiotics or isotretinoin).

Description: An allergic reaction to airborne particles like pollen, causing symptoms like sneezing, nasal congestion, and itchy eyes.
Cause: Allergic response to airborne allergens (pollen, dust mites, pet dander).
Management: Antihistamines, nasal corticosteroids, decongestants, and allergen avoidance; immunotherapy may be considered.

Description: A fungal infection that affects the skin on the feet, causing itching, redness, and peeling.
Cause: Fungal infection (tinea pedis) commonly due to dermatophytes thriving in moist environments.
Management: Topical antifungal creams or powders; keep feet clean and dry; severe cases may require oral antifungals.

Description: Painful, pus-filled bumps that form under the skin when hair follicles become infected.
Cause: Bacterial infection (usually Staphylococcus aureus) of hair follicles or oil glands.
Management: Warm compresses, incision and drainage if necessary, and antibiotics for extensive or recurrent infections.

Description: Small, painful ulcers that appear inside the mouth, often triggered by stress, certain foods, or trauma.
Cause: Painful oral ulcers triggered by stress, minor trauma, or certain foods.
Management: Topical corticosteroids, analgesic mouthwashes, and maintaining good oral hygiene; usually self-resolving.

Description: Also known as pink eye, it is an infection or inflammation of the eye's conjunctiva, causing redness, itching, and discharge.
Cause: Inflammation of the conjunctiva due to viral, bacterial, or allergic causes.
Management: Antibiotic eye drops (for bacterial), supportive care (for viral), antihistamines (for allergic), and proper hygiene.

Description: Difficulty or infrequent bowel movements, often causing discomfort, bloating, and abdominal pain.
Cause: Often due to low dietary fiber, dehydration, sedentary lifestyle, or certain medications.
Management: Increased fiber and fluid intake, regular exercise, and laxatives if necessary under medical guidance.

Description: Thickened skin that forms due to pressure or friction, typically on the feet or hands.
Cause: Thickened skin from repeated friction or pressure (commonly on the feet).
Management: Protective padding, gentle removal with a pumice stone, proper footwear; severe cases may require professional care.

Description: Flaky, dry skin on the scalp, often accompanied by itching.
Cause: Often related to seborrheic dermatitis or dry scalp conditions.
Management: Use of anti-dandruff shampoos (containing zinc pyrithione, ketoconazole, or selenium sulfide) and scalp care.

Description: A condition caused by excessive loss of water from the body, leading to symptoms like dry mouth, fatigue, and dizziness.
Cause: Loss of body fluids from inadequate intake, excessive sweating, vomiting, or diarrhea.
Management: Rehydration with fluids and electrolytes (oral rehydration solutions or IV fluids in severe cases) and treating the underlying cause.

Description: Inflammation of the skin, causing redness, itching, and sometimes blisters.
Cause: Inflammation of the skin due to irritants, allergens, or genetic predisposition.
Management: Topical corticosteroids, moisturizers, and avoidance of known triggers.

Description: Frequent, loose, and watery stools, often caused by infection, food intolerance, or gastrointestinal disorders.
Cause: Often caused by infections (viral, bacterial, parasitic), food poisoning, or medication side effects.
Management: Rehydration (oral rehydration solutions), dietary modifications, and antibiotics if a bacterial cause is confirmed.

Description: An infection of the middle ear, leading to pain, hearing loss, and sometimes fever.
Cause: Bacterial or viral infection of the middle ear, common in children.
Management: Pain management (analgesics), sometimes antibiotics, and warm compresses; maintain proper ear hygiene.

Description: Excessive gas in the digestive system, leading to bloating, belching, and passing gas.
Cause: Excess gas from swallowed air or the breakdown of certain foods by gut bacteria.
Management: Dietary modifications, slower eating habits, and over-the-counter anti-gas medications (e.g., simethicone).

Description: An illness caused by consuming contaminated food or water, leading to symptoms like vomiting, diarrhea, and stomach cramps.
Cause: Ingestion of food contaminated with bacteria, viruses, parasites, or toxins.
Management: Supportive care with rehydration, rest, and, when appropriate, antibiotics; prevention via safe food handling practices.

Description: Infections caused by fungi, often affecting the skin, nails, or lungs.
Cause: Infections caused by fungi in warm, moist environments (skin, nails, etc.).
Management: Topical or oral antifungal medications; keeping affected areas clean and dry is essential.

Description: Inflammation of the stomach lining, often causing nausea, vomiting, and stomach pain.
Cause: Inflammation of the stomach lining due to H. pylori infection, alcohol use, or NSAIDs.
Management: Use of antacids, proton pump inhibitors or H2 blockers, and antibiotics when H. pylori is present; dietary adjustments.

Description: A viral infection commonly affecting children, causing fever, mouth sores, and a rash on the hands and feet.
Cause: Viral infection (commonly coxsackievirus) affecting mainly children.
Management: Supportive care (hydration, pain management), fever reducers, and isolation during the contagious period.

Description: A burning sensation in the chest caused by acid reflux, where stomach acid backs up into the esophagus.
Cause: Acid reflux from a weakened lower esophageal sphincter or dietary triggers.
Management: Antacids, H2 blockers, proton pump inhibitors, and lifestyle modifications (avoiding trigger foods, not eating late at night).

Description: A rash caused by sweating in hot and humid conditions, leading to small red bumps and discomfort.
Cause: Blocked sweat ducts in hot, humid conditions leading to skin irritation.
Management: Cooling measures, loose clothing, topical calamine or hydrocortisone creams, and keeping the skin dry.

Description: Swollen blood vessels in the rectum, often causing pain, bleeding, and itching.
Cause: Swollen veins in the rectal area due to straining, constipation, or pregnancy.
Management: High-fiber diet, sitz baths, topical treatments, and in severe cases, procedural interventions.

Description: Red, itchy welts that appear on the skin, often triggered by allergies, stress, or infections.
Cause: Allergic reaction causing raised, itchy welts from histamine release.
Management: Antihistamines, corticosteroids for severe cases, and avoidance of known allergens.

Description: Discomfort or pain in the stomach, often caused by overeating, eating spicy foods, or stress.
Cause: Discomfort from overeating or consuming fatty/spicy foods.
Management: Antacids, dietary adjustments, and stress management; sometimes prokinetic agents are used.

Description: Condition where the edge of a toenail grows into the surrounding skin, causing pain and potential infection.
Cause: Nail edge grows into the surrounding skin due to improper trimming or tight footwear.
Management: Soaking in warm water, proper nail trimming techniques, and, if necessary, minor surgical intervention.

Description: A fungal infection that causes itching, redness, and irritation in the groin area.
Cause: Fungal infection in the groin area, exacerbated by warmth and moisture.
Management: Topical antifungal creams, keeping the area clean and dry, and avoiding tight clothing.

Description: A parasitic infection caused by lice, leading to itching and discomfort, typically affecting the scalp, body, or pubic region.
Cause: Parasitic infestation (often scalp lice) transmitted through close contact.
Management: Over-the-counter or prescription lice treatments (shampoos, lotions), combing to remove nits, and treating close contacts.

Description: Skin redness and irritation caused by overexposure to sunlight.
Cause: Skin inflammation due to overexposure to UV radiation.
Management: Cool compresses, moisturizers (preferably aloe vera), pain relievers, and avoiding further sun exposure.

Description: Blockage of the nasal passages, often caused by colds, allergies, or sinus infections.
Cause: Inflammation of nasal passages from infections, allergies, or irritants.
Management: Saline nasal sprays, decongestants, antihistamines, and steam inhalation.

Description: Bleeding from the nose, often caused by dryness, trauma, or underlying health conditions.
Cause: Rupture of small nasal blood vessels, often from dry air or minor trauma.
Management: Pinching the nostrils, leaning forward, cold compresses, and humidifying indoor air; seek care if recurrent.

Description: A fungal infection in the mouth caused by Candida, leading to white patches on the tongue and inside the cheeks.
Cause: Overgrowth of Candida in the mouth, common in infants or immunocompromised individuals.
Management: Topical or oral antifungal medications (e.g., nystatin, clotrimazole) and improved oral hygiene.

Description: A fungal infection of the skin that causes discolored patches, often on the chest, back, and arms.
Cause: Superficial fungal infection (Malassezia species) causing skin discoloration.
Management: Topical antifungal treatments (selenium sulfide, ketoconazole) and maintaining a dry, clean skin environment.

Description: Pain or irritation in the throat, often caused by viral infections, bacterial infections, or environmental factors.
Cause: Inflammation of the throat due to viral or bacterial infections.
Management: Throat lozenges, warm salt water gargles, pain relievers, and antibiotics if a bacterial cause is confirmed.

Description: Painful, swollen bumps on the eyelid caused by an infected eyelash follicle or oil gland.
Cause: Bacterial infection of an eyelid gland (often Staphylococcus aureus).
Management: Warm compresses, proper eyelid hygiene, and antibiotic ointments or oral antibiotics if necessary.

Description: The destruction of tooth structure caused by bacteria, leading to cavities, pain, and possible tooth loss.
Cause: Destruction of tooth enamel by acids produced from plaque bacteria.
Management: Dental treatments (fillings, crowns, root canals) and preventive care (brushing, flossing, fluoride toothpaste).

Description: Small growths on the skin caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV), typically appearing on the hands, feet, or face.
Cause: Skin growths caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) infection.
Management: Topical salicylic acid, cryotherapy, or other dermatologic removal methods; avoid picking to prevent spread.
